topics.name: Simple Interest
topics.description: Interest calculated on the principal only using the formula: $SI=\dfrac{P\times T\times R}{100}$
topics.hint: Convert time to years and rate to percent before applying the formula.

topics.name: Compound Interest
topics.description: Interest calculated on principal and accumulated interest using the formula: $A=P\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}\right)^T$
topics.hint: Amount = Principal × (1 + rate/100)^time. CI = Amount - Principal.

topics.name: Profit and Loss
topics.description: Calculations involving Cost Price (CP), Selling Price (SP), Profit, Loss, and percentages.
topics.hint: Profit = SP - CP (when SP > CP), Loss = CP - SP (when CP > SP). Profit% = (Profit/CP) × 100.

questions.question: Do you remember the formula for calculating Simple Interest?
questions.explanation: The correct formula is $SI=\dfrac{P\times T\times R}{100}$.

questions.question: If the principal is ₹1000, rate is 10% and time is 2 years, what is the Simple Interest?
Find SI for ₹1500 at 7% p.a. for 1 year.
Time is given in months. For SI, convert to years. 18 months equals how many years?
Find the SI if ₹1500 is deposited for 80 days at 7.3% p.a. (use 365 days).
A sum becomes ₹4400 in 2 years and ₹5000 in 5 years at SI. What is the rate p.a.?
questions.explanation: 3-year interest = 5000-4400=600 ⇒ 1-year interest=200. Principal=4400-400=4000. So $200=\dfrac{4000\times R}{100}$ ⇒ R=5%.

questions.question: At SI, a sum doubles in 8 years. In how many years will it triple?
questions.explanation: If it doubles in 8 years, r=12.5% p.a. For tripling, need interest=2P ⇒ t=2/0.125=16 years.

questions.question: The SI on a sum of money for 2 years at 12% p.a. is ₹960. Find the principal.
A sum amounts to ₹5300 in 3 years and ₹5800 in 5 years at the same SI rate. Find the principal.
If the SI on a sum for 4 years at 9% p.a. is ₹1440, find the amount at the end.
What is the formula for calculating Compound Interest Amount?
questions.explanation: The correct formula for compound interest is $A=P\left(1+\dfrac{R}{100}\right)^T$, where A is amount, P is principal, R is rate, and T is time.

options: SI is on principal only, CI is on principal + interest
SI is always more than CI
questions.explanation: Simple Interest is calculated only on the principal, while Compound Interest is calculated on principal plus accumulated interest.

What is the selling price if CP = ₹1000 and profit is 10%?
A shopkeeper sells an article at 20% profit. If CP was ₹500, find SP.
An article is sold at ₹360 resulting in 20% loss. What was the CP?
If selling price is doubled, profit becomes tripled. Find the original profit percentage.
questions.explanation: Let CP=x, SP=y, Profit=y-x. New SP=2y, New Profit=2y-x=3(y-x) ⇒ y=2x. Original Profit% = (x/x)×100 = 100%.

questions.question: A trader marks goods 40% above CP and gives 20% discount. Find profit%.
Two articles sold at ₹600 each. One at 20% profit, other at 20% loss. Find overall profit/loss.
A dishonest dealer uses 900g weight instead of 1kg and claims to sell at CP. Find profit%.
questions.explanation: He pays for 900g but sells as 1000g. Profit = 100g on 900g = (100/900)×100 = 11.11%.
